title: The common starting moves of Electrical Engineering
summary: In chess, strong players do not start each game from scratch. They study opening books — collections of proven first moves that reliably lead to stable, playable positions. Electrical engineering is no different.
content:
While products vary widely in purpose, form factor, and complexity, most successful electronic systems are built from a small set of recurring circuit strategies that appear again and again across industries.

This blog is an attempt to catalog those strategies.

Rather than focusing on isolated textbook problems or novelty circuits, the goal is to document the core electrical “moves” that nearly every real product uses: power entry and protection, voltage regulation, signal conditioning, amplification, filtering, conversion between analog and digital domains, and safe interaction with the outside world. These are the circuits that quietly underpin consumer electronics, industrial controls, medical devices, and instrumentation alike.

Over time, this blog will form a practical “opening book” for electrical engineering — a reference for students, hobbyists, and early-career engineers who want to recognize proven patterns, avoid common mistakes, and understand how real products are constructed. The emphasis is on clarity, repeatability, and reasoning, not memorization.

Lets begin with power








**Source Reference Design:
Texas Instruments PMP21783 / PMP21783.2
“60-W Ultra-Wide Range Isolated Flyback-Quasi Resonant Power Supply”
Schematic, PCB layout, and documentation courtesy of Texas Instruments.
**



![image description](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Ascendss/MBEngineering-main/main/assets/uploads/1765587915237-5e8a1b.png)

![image description](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Ascendss/MBEngineering-main/main/assets/uploads/1765587925451-326c48.png)
Figure: Quasi-resonant isolated flyback power supply reference design
Source: Texas Instruments, PMP21783 Reference Design
https://www.ti.com/reference-designs


![image description](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Ascendss/MBEngineering-main/main/assets/uploads/1765588593579-cb87e8.png)






**Move 1: Power Entry & Front End
AC and DC Input Conditioning into a Common High-Voltage DC Bus**

The purpose of the power entry stage is to accept multiple real-world power sources and convert them into a single high-voltage DC bus suitable for the isolated flyback converter. In this design, Texas Instruments supports both 85–265 VAC and 24–150 VDC inputs by handling each input type separately and normalizing them early in the system.





**Move 1A: AC Input Path (85–265 VAC)
AC Input Connector and Fuse**

J2: AC line and neutral input connector

F1: Line fuse

The AC mains enter the board through connector J2. The fuse F1 provides primary safety protection by opening under sustained overcurrent conditions. This protects downstream components and is required for any mains-powered design.




EMI / Line Filter

C13: X-class line capacitor

L3: Common-mode choke

After the fuse, the AC input passes through an EMI filter consisting of C13 and L3. This network reduces conducted electromagnetic interference in both directions:

It prevents high-frequency switching noise generated inside the power supply from returning to the AC mains.

It attenuates external line noise before it enters the system.

This block is critical for regulatory compliance (EMI/EMC).

Bridge Rectifier

D8: Bridge rectifier (KBP06G)

The filtered AC waveform is rectified by D8, converting the bipolar AC input into a unipolar, pulsating DC waveform. After rectification, the voltage magnitude depends directly on the AC input level.

For the supported input range, the resulting DC voltage is approximately:

~120 VDC at low line (85 VAC)

~375 VDC at high line (265 VAC)

Bulk Energy Storage

Downstream bulk capacitors (high-voltage electrolytics)

Bulk capacitors immediately following the bridge rectifier smooth the rectified waveform and store energy between AC line peaks. These capacitors supply the flyback converter during short line dropouts and reduce ripple on the high-voltage DC bus.

At this point, the AC input path has produced an unregulated high-voltage DC rail.

Move 1B: DC Input Path (24–150 VDC)
DC Input Connector

J1: 24–250 VDC input connector

The DC input enters through J1, supporting a wide DC voltage range. Unlike the AC path, this input may be too low to directly operate the flyback stage efficiently.

DC Input Filtering and Sensing

R1, R4, R5, R8: Input sensing and bias resistors

C9, C30, C31: Input decoupling capacitors

TP1: Test point on the DC input rail

These components provide:

Basic filtering to reduce input noise

Voltage sensing for control and protection functions

Local energy storage for transient current demands

Boost Converter Stage (DC Input Only)

Q1: Boost MOSFET

L1: Boost inductor

D1: High-speed boost diode

C6, C5: Boost output capacitors

Boost output labeled “Boost to 150 V”

When the DC input voltage is below the required flyback operating range, the boost converter raises it to approximately 150 VDC. This allows the flyback stage to operate from a consistent input voltage, regardless of whether power originates from AC or DC.

This boost stage is bypassed when the input voltage is already sufficiently high.

Unified High-Voltage DC Bus

Both the AC rectified output and the boosted DC input converge onto a common high-voltage DC bus that feeds the primary side of the flyback converter.

Key architectural advantage:

The flyback stage sees a known voltage range

Control complexity is isolated to the front end

AC/DC dual-input support is achieved without duplicating the main power stage

From this point forward, the remainder of the system does not distinguish between AC or DC input sources.
